page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: For an area which loses five squares to the sea East Brighton has considerable variety. To the West where it is close to the centre of the town it is a densely populated urban area of older housing with some fine Regency buildings and squares overlooking the sea. Further East towards the edge of the town there are council and suburban estates both overlooking and lying within the valleys stretching back into the South Downs. Downland devoted to farming and recreational facilities separates the urban area from Ovingdean, an old village which has now expanded into a commuter suburb. Shingle beaches backed by a promenade with an amusement area form the western part of the coast. The central area is dominated by a marina and the eastern section has chalk cliffs up to 100 ft.
